skill.name: doc-coauthoring
skill.description: Guide users through a structured workflow for co-authoring documentation. Use when user wants to write documentation, proposals, technical specs, decision docs, or similar structured content. This workflow helps users efficiently transfer context, refine content through iteration, and verify the doc works for readers. Trigger when user mentions writing docs, creating proposals, drafting specs, or similar documentation tasks.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-only documentation workflow skill. It contains no executable code, makes no network calls, and has no file system access beyond the user's working directory. All actions are user-initiated and transparent.

content.user_title: Create better documentation through structured co-authoring
content.value_statement: Writing documentation alone often produces docs that confuse readers. This skill guides you through a proven three-stage workflow‚Äîcontext gathering, iterative refinement, and reader testing‚Äîto create documents that actually work for your audience.
actual_capabilities: Guides users through three-stage documentation workflow
Helps gather context through targeted questioning
Iteratively builds and refines document sections
Tests document clarity with fresh Claude instance
Creates structured markdown artifacts or files
Manages document quality through curation and editing
limitations: Requires user participation at each stage
Cannot access external integrations without user configuration
Does not generate content without user input and approval
Relies on user to verify technical accuracy

use_cases.title: Write technical specs and design docs
use_cases.description: Create clear technical specifications and design documents that help your team understand implementation details and architectural decisions.

use_cases.title: Draft proposals and PRDs
use_cases.description: Develop product requirement documents and proposals that communicate requirements clearly to engineering and stakeholders.

use_cases.title: Create decision docs and RFCs
use_cases.description: Document architectural decisions and RFCs that capture trade-offs and reasoning for future reference and team alignment.

prompt_templates.title: Start Documentation Project
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me write a [document type] about [topic]. Let's use the structured co-authoring workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Refine Existing Draft
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a draft document I want to improve. Let me paste it in and we'll use the workflow to refine it section by section.

prompt_templates.title: Reader Testing
prompt_templates.prompt: My document is drafted. Let's run reader testing to see if a fresh Claude can understand it and answer questions about it correctly.

prompt_templates.title: Team Documentation
prompt_templates.prompt: We need to document our [system/process] for the team. Guide us through creating comprehensive documentation that future team members can understand.

output_examples.input: Help me write a technical spec for our new authentication system using the co-authoring workflow.
output: I'd be happy to help you create a technical spec through our structured co-authoring workflow.
This approach has three stages: (1) Context Gathering, (2) Refinement & Structure, and (3) Reader Testing.
Shall we proceed? If you prefer to work freeform instead, I can do that too.

best_practices: Provide all relevant context upfront‚Äîdon't worry about organizing it
Be specific when requesting edits so Claude can learn your preferences
Use reader testing to catch assumptions that make sense to you but confuse others
Iterate through each section until it feels complete before moving on
anti_patterns: Skipping context gathering and expecting Claude to fill in gaps
Editing the document directly instead of asking for changes
Skipping reader testing and assuming the document works for others
Rushing through stages without addressing gaps or ambiguities

faq.question: What document types work best with this skill?
faq.answer: Technical specs, PRDs, design docs, decision records, RFCs, proposals, and any structured documentation requiring clarity.

faq.question: How long does the workflow typically take?
faq.answer: Varies by document complexity. Plan for multiple sessions for substantial documents. Each stage requires user participation.

faq.question: Can I skip stages if I'm in a hurry?
faq.answer: You can skip stages, but quality may suffer. Reader testing catches issues that are hard to spot as the author.

faq.question: Does this work with Google Docs or SharePoint?
faq.answer: Only if you have connectors enabled in your Claude settings. Otherwise, paste content directly or share links.

faq.question: Is my data safe with this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This is a prompt-only skill. All context you provide stays in your conversation. No data is sent externally.

faq.question: How is this different from regular Claude prompting?
faq.answer: The structured workflow prevents common documentation failures: missing context, unclear assumptions, and reader confusion.
